pullRequest.body:
add coercion theorems for: one, zero, add and mul; an interaction with algebraMap; and a theorem showing how algebraMaps of extensions are built. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [951903e724](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19814/commits/951903e72473452c1ba96d3a102845541f6203ec)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ coe_add`
`+ coe_algebraMap`
`+ coe_mul`
`+ coe_one`
`+ coe_zero:`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Sorry to take so long about this -- Christmas and then start of term!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12736736104/job/35496984909)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12736736104/job/35496985011)
Can you add a docstring to your definitions? thats why CI is failing.
Do you need all of these? cant you reuse some of the ones from above?
You're right I am able to shorten this quite a bit.

Can you explain what the point of this definition is and why it's tagged `@[coe]`? Just to be clear -- this isn't some smarty-pants way of telling you that this is the wrong thing to do! Quite the opposite -- I'm just showing my genuine ignorance about how the coercion system works. Here's some code which works already on `master`:
```lean
import Mathlib.RingTheory.DedekindDomain.FiniteAdeleRing

variable (R : Type*) (K : Type*) [CommRing R] [IsDedekindDomain R] [Field K]
  [Algebra R K] [IsFractionRing R K]

open DedekindDomain

local notation "K_hat" => ProdAdicCompletions

/- we already have this on master:

instance : Coe (FiniteAdeleRing R K) (K_hat R K) where
  coe x := x.1

-/

example (x : FiniteAdeleRing R K) : False := by
  -- the coercion works already
  let y : K_hat R K := x
  -- it also displays correctly
  -- `y : K_hat R K := ↑x`
  sorry
```

So what does your code give us that we don't have already? (I'm asking in the sense of "I don't know, but there might be a good answer to this")

No worries for the question. I am far from an expert on coercions myself so I began by replicating other coercion examples I have seen and used (specifically, line 128 in Mathlib/Algebra/Quaternions) - here they had both def and instance, so this is why I added the definition. But upon more looking I think you are right that the definition is unnecessary (that is it adds nothing new) in this case as the instance introduces it as a function (unlike in the quaternion file). @[coe] was added as I presumed that is what allows the delaborator to use the `\u` notation - the tooltip for it also says it should be included in instances like we have, so maybe someone with more knowledge could explain how it already works without the tag?

I would be happy to remove this definition in a new commit, unless you think it is idiomatic to keep it and change the instance so that it matches the style used in the quaternion file. I am unsure what the standard preferred convention is?

These lemmas are all fine, but I am a bit confused about why we want to coerce to K_hat in the first place. What is the application here? I was hoping that we'd be able to do everything in `FiniteAdeleRing R K` without ever mentioning K_hat again (I regard K_hat as an implentation detail). Is this not the case?

These lemmas were added via your suggestion in my PR 269 of FLT [](https://github.com/ImperialCollegeLondon/FLT/pull/269/files) the application being that FiniteAdeleRing.baseChange was built from the ProdAdicCompletions.baseChange and these facts were needed in the proof. I guess the answer to your question depends how often we will be defining maps on the FiniteAdeleRing via maps on K_hat and taking their restriction?
Fair enough, let's leave them there for convenience's sake. We'll have to do some more coercing for FLT I guess.

This theorem I am a bit confused about. We have it already -- as you note in your proof, it's called `IsScalarTower.algebraMap_apply`. Why do we want a new name for it? Furthermore I don't think `algebraMap_extension` is the correct name for this. Searching through mathlib, `_extension` seems to be used for extending a set to a bigger set, or extending a function from a dense subspace. Probably it should just be called `algebraMap_apply` again? But this just brings me back to the question about why we need it at all.

As above I included it from your recommendation; but I also felt that it was maybe unnecessary. Perhaps in the linked PR you meant another statement as I admit my naming of have's was not the most clear and consistent?

But, I agree it is not needed, as I returned to my code I submitted for 269 on FLT and you can replace the have i with a rw [IsScalarTower...].
I am happy to remove the algebra section (just this theorem) in the next commit.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: coe theorems in FiniteAdeleRing
